--- "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains762@...> wrote:
> >This only works for arrays that must be ordered.  What about
> unordered
> >arrays? [...]
> 
> Jason, I think you mean "not indexed". Arrays are not "ordered" (in
> the  mathematical sense), they are "indexed". If you need a
collection

Sounds like a case where an array is being used to collect (with an
order implied by the index) something that is actually unordered and a
desire to have the test ignore ordering. An unordered collection is the
way to go here.

I've actually got some tests now that require a partial ordering of
results. Unfortunately, our current tests only compare against one
legal ordering (which means the test only works reliably when the
threading code is disabled). My unconcious mind keeps telling me I
should write (or find) a directed (acyclic) graph class to hold the
expected results and verify that the actual results are a legal
topological sort based on the partial ordering of the graph. Haven't
actually done it.

Regards,

Rob
